review: We bought one to see how it compared to our old Roku2. Streams load faster and don't seem to require the "warmup" period we experienced on the Roku where it took a bit for the streams to clear up and and display at full resolution. It's faster. The UI could use a bit of streamlining, but it's really pretty simple to use. Plus, we're able to get stable streams via WiFi, whereas with the Roku we needed to bypass wireless and go with an Ethernet connection. All in all I like it.My complaint has to do with Ultraviolet support. Because of the ability to convert old DVDs and Blu-Rays to HD online versions, we've converted most of our discs to Ultraviolet. We'd watch them on our Roku using the Vudu app, and they looked and sounded great, and it was really convenient.Unfortunately, the Flixster app on the Fire TV won't play in HD, and that's proving to be a real source of frustration. I contacted Flixster, and they said that ability might come in the future, but there doesn't seem to be a good idea about when. I'd appreciate it if Amazon would make this a priority.

review: WonderfulSlim, Fast, voice search, expandable with Android apps (like airtight to make airplay target, xbmc to make it full media center), remote control, games.AwfulNetwork disconnects, if you have parental control checked and network disconnects you are locked as setting up network requires parental control, which itself requires network connectivity, usb can not be used for external storage, OOB experience is bad as it requires a full update, no power off so sometimes amazon firetv wakes up in the middle of night and because of hdmi CEC switches the LED tv.Still 4 star as it's all in one (netflix, huluplus, airplay target, games, xbmc) and has bluetooth remote so I can hide the console inside a cabin.
author: Nugeek

review: I currently have in my house:1) XBOX 3602) ChromecastAnd now -- Amazon Fire TVThis allows me to have streaming capability in three (3) rooms in my house and also to compare each device.1) Xbox -- have had for quite awhile and enjoy using it as it is very easy to use -- allows me to stream Amazon Prime and Netflix -- and also play games.2) Chromecast -- very inexpensive device that allows me to control it through my smartphone. Allows me to stream Netflix -- but not Amazon Prime.3) Amazon Fire TV -- absolutely love this device -- quick and easy to setup and unless I am just imagining it -- it works ALOT faster than my other devices. Netflix seems to load faster and quality "seems" better -- but again maybe I am just imagining it? Regardless, the Amazon Fire device definitely moves faster in terms of start-up and navigation throughout. Finally, the voice search feature is AWESOME -- it is very cool to be able to say "Robert DeNiro" and then have everything he has ever been in pop-up on-screen!

review: I'm a big fan of Amazon. When Fire T.V. came out I bought one on the day it came out. I wanted to see if it was as good if not better than my beloved Roku's (I currently own 4 of them). Fire T.V. has some nice features that I like such as: voice search (however, it's limited to amazon content only), parental controls, it's fast and my kids love the gaming features.The biggest issue I have is with the interface. It not very well organized. Searching through Amazon content alone is tedious, even more so if it's not Amazon content. I prefer Amazon's app on Roku. Just my opinion, but I feel it's a lot more organized and easier to search. I don't always have something in mind I'm looking for, so the voice feature on the Fire T.V. doesn't help me much in that respect. I want an easier way to browse ALL the prime content, just to see if there's something on there I want to watch. It's something I can do on the Roku, but not the Fire T.V.  Lastly, I buy all my digital movies from Amazon Video. I currently own over 80 digital movies. I was really surprised (and disappointed) that Amazon didn't incorporate the special deals feature from their app on Roku to the Fire T.V. I frequently browse and purchase from there.Overall I'm happy with my purchase, though I still prefer my Roku to the Fire T.V. My kids certainly love the Fire T.V for it's voice search and games, and that's important to me and my wallet! While I think the interface needs better organization for content (everything else is superb), I'm confident Amazon will get that worked out.
